bibl.title: Personal History of Candidate: James Carroll, October 18, 1902

div1.p: Carroll submits his personal history to the Medical Board for part of his examination for the Army Medical Corps. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Personal History of Candidate: James Carroll, October 18, 1902
div1.p: Personal History of Candidate.
Carroll
Name in full. James Carroll
Place of birth. Woolwich, England.
Date of birth. June 5, 1854.
Permanent residence. Army.
Married or single. Married
Number of Children. Five.

Nature and date of any and all serious sicknesses or injuries. Typhoid fever, in
the service, at Rock Springs, Wyo., in 1887;
Experimental yellow fever, in the service, at
Havana, Cuba, August-September 1900.
Are you sound and well now, and physically able to perform all the duties of a medical officer? Yes.

If either parent, brother, or sister has died, state cause and age. Father, of old age;
one sister, of esophageal cancer.
Have you given up any pursuit on account of ill health? No.

What academy, high school, college, or university have you attended? Give dates; were you graduated?
Albion House Academy, Albion Road, Woolwich, Eng., until 1869.
No.

Name any other educational advantage, such as private tuition, foreign travel, etc.
None.

Give literary or scientific degree, if any, name of institution granting it, and date.
None.

With what ancient or modern languages or branches of science are you acquainted? Studied French,
for one year at school; German for two years more recently.

When did you begin the study of medicine, and under whose direction? His residence.
In 1884, at Fort Custer, Montana, under Dr. James E. Pilcher,
then 1st-Lieut and Ass't Surgeon U. S. Army.

How many courses of lectures have you attended? Names of colleges and dates. Three.
University of the City of New York, 1886-7; University of Maryland,
1889-90 and 1890-91.

When and where were you graduated in medicine?
In 1891 from the University of MaryLand at Baltimore.
Have you been an interne in a hospital? Where and for what period? No.

What clinical experience have you had in dispensary or private practice? The clinical experience
incident upon ten years service at military posts as Hospital Steward;
private courses in physical diagnosis, gynecology and venereal diseases
in New York City; one year's private practice.

Have you paid particular attention to any specialty in medicine? Private courses in Bacteriology
and Pathology at the John's Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, in 1891-2 and 1892-3.
Have taught these subjects and clinical microscopy in the medical Department of
Columbian University, Washington, D.C. for six or eight years.

What opportunities for instruction or practice in operative surgery have you had?
One private course in operative surgery.

Have you been in the military or naval service as cadet or otherwise? In the military
service since January 1874 as enlisted man and Contract Surgeon.

What occupation, if any, have you followed other than that of student or practitioner?
As a boy I was a slender stripling imbued with a
strong desire for an active outdoor life. Before entering
the army, I declined employment involving clinical work
or confinement and worked for several years as blacksmith's
helper, railroad laborer, cordwood chopper etc.

Address. Army Medical Museum, S.G.O.
Date. October 18, 1902. Name. James Carroll.
